Algebraic Optimization
Prev Samples and Tutorials Next

Algebraic Optimization

Objective and Overview

This tutorial optimizes a chosen criterion - or, more specifically, finds the values of chosen variables that bring the minimum value to a chosen criterion function. The tutorial's goal is to demonstrate how the GMAT's optimizer works. Examples of the use of optimization in real missions include minimizing the amount of fuel used by the mission or minimizing the mission flight time while achieving certain characteristics of the mission. In order to learn how to optimize a mission sequence one needs to be familiar with optimizers, nonlinear constraints, and the minimize command - which is what this tutorial will cover.

You can download the tutorial's script file, Ex_AlgebraicOptimization.script , and run it beforehand, to observe the expected final results.

Prerequisites

  • Basic Understanding of how to create and propagate a spacecraft, as in Tutorial Creating and Propagating a Spacecraft

Mission Description

  • Objective: The goal here is to find values of variables X1 and X2 that minimize a criterion function F, with a constraint that X1+X2=8, as follows:

    F = ( X1 - 2 )2 + ( X2 - 2 )2

    G = X1 + X2

    G = 8

  • Find: Values X1 and X2

Note that the constraint G makes our problem one of conditional optimization. With no constraint G, the function F minimum would obviously correspond to X1=2, X2=2, thus F=0. But this solution is not possible due to G = X1 + X2 = 8. At the end of this tutorial, after we solve our original problem, for exersize we will request GMAT to produce the unconditional F value as well.

Configuring the Resource Tree

Objects Required

  • Optimizer: VF13ad1

  • Plots/Reports: Report Data

  • Variables: X1, X2, F, G

Creating and Modifying Resource Tree Objects

We will create/modify the following objects: the optimizer (in section Solvers of the Resource Tree); the report (in Output); and variables (in Variables/Arrays/Strings). GMAT defaults will be used for other mission resources.

  • Solvers: Add to the sequence the VF13ad1 optimizer. We will use the optimizer's default characteristics. The figure below shows how this dialog box looks like

    Figure: VF13ad1 Boundary Value Solver Object

  • Plots/Reports: Set up the Data ReportFile. Your ReportFile dialog box should look as in the figure below

    • Clear Parameter List

    • Save at ./output/SampleMissions/Ex_AlgebraicOptimization.report

    Figure: Data ReportFile System Object

  • Variables/Strings/Arrays: Set the initial values, as follows:

    • Variable X1 = 0

    • Variable X2 = 0

    • Variable F = 0

    • Variable G = 0. Your last Variables/Strings/Arrays dialog box should look as shown in this figure:

    Figure: ReportFile System Object

Now your Resource Tree should look as shown in this figure:

Figure: Algebraic Optimization Resource Tree

Creating and Configuring the Mission Tree

Set up the Mission Tree and the Output Tree; when done, they should look as in the two figures below

Figure 1. Figure: Mission Tree


Figure 2. Figure: Output Tree


Creating and Modifying Command Sequences

As said above, values X1 and X2 are independent variables of the function F that is to be optimized. The sum of X1 and X2 form a constraint G, G=X1+X2=8. The final values of F, X1, X2 are to be sent to a report file. In this section we will set up the optimization command sequence, as in the Optimize sequence below. Optimization is done in Equation1, via the optimization criterion function F, using the Matlab routine SQPfmincon. For the constraint G, since a function cannot be a constraint in itself, the value G is used. This is done in Equation2.

You set up the commands using the corresponding dialog boxes. When done, the dialog boxes for commands in the Mission Tree - Vary1, Vary2, Equation1, Minimize1, Equation2, NonlinearConstraint1, and Report1 - should look like as shown in the figures below.

  • Optimize

    • Vary X1 using SQPfmincon

      • Upper = 10, Lower = -10

    • Vary X2 using SQPfmincon

      • Upper = 10, Lower = -10

    • Equation1: F = ( X1 - 2 )2 + ( X2 - 2 )2

    • Minimize the value of F using SQPfmincon

    • Equation2: G = X1 + X2

    • Set the Nonlinear Constraint G = 8 using SQPfmincon

  • Report to file Data the values of variables F, G, X1, X2

Figure: Vary X1 Command

Figure: Vary X2 Command

Figure: Equation1 Command

Figure: Minimize F Command

Figure: Equation2 Command

Figure: Nonlinear Constraint Command

Figure: Report Command

Running the Mission

There is no plot for this mission sequence. Its results - values X1, X2, the minimum value of the optimized function F, and, for completeness, the constraint value G - can be found by calling ReportFile1 in the Output Tree. The report should look like the figure below.

Figure: Data ReportFile

As an exersize, let us see what values X1, X2, and F would the optimizer deliver if we eleminate the constraint G. In the Mission Tree, remove the NonlinearConstraint1 command and run the mission again. Not surprisingly, the optimizer delivers values X1=2, X2=2, and F=0. See the ReportFile box below (value G has no meaning here).

Figure: Data ReportFile with Eliminated Constraint G
